I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1.  
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the additional financing of the Secondary 
Towns and Rural Community-Based Water Supply and Sanitation Project. 1  
 
2. 
The proposed additional financing will ensure successful completion of the head works 
of the Muttur water supply scheme. The distribution networks and elevated towers of the Muttur 
scheme are under construction. However, even after supplementary assistance2 for this project 
on  29 November  2006,  for  exogenous  reasons,  significant  price  escalation  of  key  inputs  has 
resulted  in  cost  overruns.  While  the  Government  of  Sri  Lanka  is  prepared  to  increase  its 
contribution  to  meet  the  final  cost  to  completion,  it  has  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB)  to  provide  additional  financing  from  loan  savings  to  ease  the  pressure  on  government 
funds. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The government gives high priority to the provision of and access to safe drinking water 
for  its  population.3 Under  Section  III  of  its  2001  Millennium  Development  Goals  objective,  the 
government aims by 2015 to reduce by 50% the proportion of people unable to reach or afford 
safe  drinking  water.  4  The  additional  financing  will  strengthen  the  government’s  efforts  in 
(i) promoting regionally balanced development, (ii) rehabilitating and reconstructing the conflict-
affected  areas,  and  (iii)  reducing  poverty  and  ensuring  equitable  development  in  the  conflict-
affected areas. The additional financing was included in the country operations business plan, 
2010–2012.5  
 
Project implementation is rated satisfactory despite being affected by the conflict. All but 
4. 
one of the 16 contract packages under the urban component covering the towns of Batticaloa, 
Hambantota, Muttur, and Polonnaruwa have been awarded. Nine contracts are ongoing and the 
remaining six contracts have been completed. Most of the ongoing works will be completed in 
2011—except for the salinity barrier in Hambantota, which is expected to be completed in early 
2012 well within the current loan closing date of June 2012. This overall progress is despite 18 
months  delay  in  Batticaloa  and  Muttur  caused  by  the  resurgence  of  conflict  in  these  areas 
during 2006–2007. In addition, three towns6 out of the four  in the project were affected by the 
2004  tsunami.  In  these  towns,  the  displaced  persons  were  resettled  during  2005–2006.  The

contracts resumed slowly after clearing of mines. Since the end of conflict in 2009, the working 
environment has improved and most of the work is progressing well. Nearly 81% of the 9,606 
rural  water  supply  schemes  planned  are  now  completed,  benefiting  over  130,000  people.  The 
remaining  schemes  will  be  completed  in  2011.  The  cumulative  contract  awards  to  date  are 
$112.24 million (84.1%) and cumulative disbursements are $85.96 million (64.4%).7 
 
5. 
Cost  overruns  have  been  reported  in  most  construction  operations  in  Sri  Lanka  during 
2005 to 2010 including the water supply and sanitation sector. By the time the initial contracts 
were due for award in 2005 following detailed design, it became apparent that there was a very 
significant  cost  overrun—estimated  at  $80.2  million.  Factors  leading  to  cost  overruns  in  the 
project  included  (i)  price  increases  and  revision  of  estimates  as  a  result  of  the  input  price 
increase in the international market and the impact of 2004 tsunami8 ($48.7 million [60%]), and 
(ii)  physical  changes  during  detailed  engineering  design  ($16.5  million  [21%]).  To  meet  the 
expected  cost  overrun,  a  supplementary  assistance  loan  (footnote  2)  for  $60  million  was 
approved in November 2006. The revised project cost was estimated at $175.2 million in 2006. 
ADB’s  loan  amount  was  increased  to  $120.3  million  equivalent  (69%)  with  funds  from  the 
Special  Funds  resources  and  ordinary  capital  resources,  the  government’s  contribution 
increased to $51.8 million (30%), while beneficiaries’ contribution remained at $3.1 million (1%). 
 
Although price and physical contingencies were built into the 2006 supplementary loan, 
6. 
significant price escalation continued through 2007–2008. As a result, for all contracts awarded, 
bid prices were well above the revised estimates in 2006. This was despite competition in the 
bidding process, with an average of three bids  being received, even in conflict-affected areas. 
From 2006 to 2009, the average cost increases for key inputs were cement 20%, metal (granite 
stone)  25%,  sand  34%,  reinforced  steel  58%,  polyvinyl  chloride  pipes  57%,  ductile  iron  pipes 
100%, fuel 23%, and labor 25%. During 2006–2009, average inflation was 12.5%, but it peaked 
in 2008 at 22.6%. As a result, the final revised cost is now estimated as $259.5 million.  
 
7. 
The  remaining  contract  to  be  awarded,  and  for  which  additional  financing  is  being 
proposed,  is  for  the  Muttur  head  works  and  treatment  plant  which  could  not  be  financed  as  a 
result of increased costs. In the case of the Muttur subproject, bids for the distribution system 
were called by mid-2006 while the original bidding for the treatment plant and head works was 
in  the  technical  proposal  stage  under  the  two-envelope  bidding  procedure.  The  tender  for  the 
distribution  network  was  awarded  in  early  2008  in  anticipation  of  awarding  the  head  works 
tender  by  mid  2008.  However,  due  to  a  poor  response  and  unreasonable  bid  prices,  the 
government and ADB decided to re-tender the head works in mid-2008. 
 
8. 
Involuntary resettlement. The project is classified involuntary resettlement category B. 
The  NWSDB  prepared  a  short  resettlement  plan  during  initial  project  appraisal,  in accordance 
with  the  government’s  National  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy 9  and  ADB’s  applicable 
safeguard  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement  (1995).  All  land  acquisition  is  completed  and 
compensation  paid.  The  proposed  activity  under  this  additional  financing  is  within  the  original 
scope; the current short resettlement plan is valid and no revision is needed. However, ADB will 
continuously monitor for any physical changes during implementation.

The  project  promotes  equal  representation  of  women  in  staffing,  planning,  and 
11. 
implementation of the project. Numerical targets set for the project have been met or exceeded, 
and women’s involvement in project implementation is high. Also, women’s participation in the 
rural component of the project was comprehensive because the gender action plan provisions 
were  implemented  effectively.  Implementing  partner  nongovernment  organizations  established 
new  community-based  organizations  to  manage  rural  water  supply  schemes.  A  recent 
review shows  that  both  women  and  men  have  equal  participation  and  leadership  positions  in 
these  community-based  organizations,  which  manage  the  rural  water  supply  schemes. 10 
Positive  changes  in  gender  relations  and  gender  roles  resulting  from  the  project  include 
women’s  leadership  in  the  community,  their  increased  involvement  in  planning  and  managing 
community infrastructure, and increased engagement with local government on identification of 
and  planning  related  to  community  needs.  Women’s  livelihood-related  activities  improved 
through access to revolving loan funds through the project, although the impact was limited as 
the loans were small.  
 
12. 
The  government  requested  ADB  to  allocate  from  portfolio  savings  (i) SDR8.148  million 
($12.773 million)  to  a  supplementary  loan  to  the  North  East  Community  Restoration  and 
Development  Project  II 11  for  urgent  rehabilitation  works  in  the  Northern  province,  and 
(ii) $13 million12 as  additional  financing  to  the  Secondary  Towns  and  Rural  Community-Based 
Water Supply and Sanitation Project for completion of the head works and water treatment plant 
in the Muttur water supply scheme in the Eastern province.13 
 
13. 
The  additional  financing  meets  the  eligibility  criteria  in  ADB’s  additional  financing 
policy,14 i.e., the project remains technically feasible, economically viable, and financially sound.

15. 

 

The  government  accords  it  high  priority  and  it  is  consistent  with  the  project’s  development 
objectives as well as the current country partnership strategy.15 The proposed assistance meets 
the  standards  for  additional  financing  of  a  well-performing  project.  The  cost  overrun  is  due  to 
exogenous reasons, and the government’s evaluation of the tender for the Muttur  head works 
has been completed and works can be completed within 24 months after the award. ADB may 
provide  additional  financing  to  ensure  successful  completion  of  ADB-financed  projects  in  the 
event  of  a  financing  gap  or  a  cost  overrun.  Other  applicable  priority  conditions  are  that  the 
project is at an advanced stage of implementation and can be completed within a relatively short 
time,  and  has  a  high  degree  of  project  readiness  in  such  areas  as  design,  implementation 
capacity,  and  safeguards.  The  additional  financing  will  meet  cost  overruns  resulting  from 
specific input price increases and overall inflation, while the project’s scope remains unchanged.  
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

14. 
The  impact  of  the  project  is  to  improve  health  conditions  in  Batticaloa,  Hambantota, 
Muttur, and Polonnaruwa by reducing (i) the incidence of waterborne diseases by 50%, (ii) the 
infant  mortality  by  20%,  and  (iii)  the  time  and  resources  that  households  spend  in  acquiring 
water  by  75%.  The  outcome  of  the  project  is  to  provide  pipe-borne  safe  drinking  water  to 
946,000 people and safe sanitation16 to 171,500 people in the project areas.   
 
C. 

Outputs 

The main outputs of the project are to: 
 
(a)  undertake  urban  schemes  -  construct  three  new  water  networks  to  provide  40,000 
m3/day in Batticaloa, 8,500 m3/day in Muttur, and 30,500 m3/day in Polonnaruwa, extend 
one  existing  water  network  to  provide  15,000 m3/day  in  Hambantota,  construct  33,000 
low-cost  latrines,  construct  Batticaloa  Hospital  waste  treatment  plan  with  capacity  to 
treat 350 m3/day, and provide training and public awareness campaigns;  
 
(b) develop rural water supply and sanitation - construct rural water schemes to provide 
drinking  water  (piped,  rainfed,  protected  well)  to  350,000  people  in  Anuradhapura, 
Batticaloa  and  Polonnaruwa,  construct  27,000  low-cost  latrines,  and  deliver  training 
programs;  
 
(c) support institutional strengthening capacity - deliver a national public awareness and 
education campaign, implement a corporate strategy to improve NWSDB management, 
implement a strategy to reduce operation and maintenance cost, implement a financial 
management  strategy,  implement  a  strategy  to  transfer  systems  with  less  than  1,000 
connections to local authorities, community-based organizations, and the private sector, 
and develop an asset registry for systems with more than 10,000 connections. 

 
16. 
The additional financing will be used to fund the head works of the Muttur water supply 
scheme. The head works include water intake, raw water transmission, and 8,500 m3/day water 
treatment  plant.  If  the  head  works  of  the  Muttur  water  supply  are  not  completed,  it  will  not  be

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

22. 
The executing agency for the project is the NWSDB under the Ministry of Water Supply

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

24. 
Economic and financial analyses were updated for each water supply scheme in the four 
towns.18 The project will benefit a population of 246,662 in Batticaloa; 145,524 in Hambantota; 
57,314  in  Muttur;  and  92,290  in  Polonnaruwa  in  2030  (the  final  year  of  analysis)  by  providing 
good  quality,  reliable  piped  water  in  the  areas.  These  figures  are  compared  to  226,724  in 
Batticaloa; 133,029  in Hambantota;  49,490  in Muttur;  and  84,128  in  Polonnaruwa  assumed  at 
the  previous  appraisal  in  2006.  Two  major  streams  of  economic  benefits  from  water  supply 
schemes are quantified: (i) resource cost savings for the non-incremental water supply from the 
project  including  savings  in  time  spent  fetching  water;  savings  in  costs  of  replacement  and 
repair of wells, bores, jars and buckets, and transportation; and savings in medical costs spent 
for  waterborne  diseases;  and  (ii)  the  value  of  the  incremental  water  supply  from  the  project. 
Without the project, the average domestic water consumption is assumed at 60 liters per capita 
per day; and with the project, 100 liters per capita per day, in line with the assumption made at 
appraisal. The average household is assumed to save 43–76 minutes per day spent in fetching 
water as a result of the project, and the time savings are evaluated at an unskilled wage rate of 
SLRs550  per  day. 19 Unquantifiable  benefits  from  the  project  include  (i)  increased  economic 
activity in the areas resulting from the more reliable water supply infrastructure, (ii) appreciation

in  land  values  caused  by  better  access  to  basic  services,  and  (iii)  psychological  benefits  of 
residents in the project areas from being designated priority areas by the government.   
 
25. 
Economic  benefits  for  water  supply  were  quantified  and  the  economic  internal  rate  of 
return  (EIRR)  was  found  to  be  highest  in  Batticaloa  (11.0%),  followed  by  Muttur  (9.5%), 
Hambantota (7.4%), and Polonnaruwa (4.6%) in order of economic viability. For the four water 
supply  schemes  combined,  the  overall  EIRR  is  estimated  at  9.1%.  This  compares  with  an 
overall  EIRR  of  10.0%  estimated  during  the  project  reevaluation  in  2006.  While  the  overall 
economic  returns  of  the  project  have  declined  with  the  escalation  of  project  costs,  the  overall 
project is viable since (i) there is significant sunk costs incurred on the project; (ii) in the post-
conflict era, significant economic development activity is occurring or planned to occur, which is 
likely  to  result  in  further  urban  migration  into  the  project  areas  leading  to  greater  demand  for 
water  from  both  domestic  and  nondomestic  consumers;  and  (iii)  a  scarcity  of  water  exists  in 
these  project  areas.  The  economic  analysis  excludes  indirect  secondary  benefits  such  as 
reduction  in  spending  on  healthcare  due  to  a  reduction  in  waterborne  disease  and  an 
improvement  in  health.  The  updated  economic  returns  estimated  for  the  respective  towns  are

As  agreed  with  the  government,  the  financial  sustainability  of  the  urban  schemes

the NWSDB’s tariffs revision effected in February 2009 following which the effective water tariff 
revenue  (considering  a  4%  real  increase  in  tariff  annually)  from  each  of  the  four  water  supply 
schemes will at minimum cover the incremental O&M costs, while three out of the four schemes 
would  also  be  able  to  cover  debt  servicing  costs  of  the  project.20 With  the  improved  financial 
performance of the NWSDB, following the tariff revisions in 2009, the capital costs of the project 
can be recovered.
